did.abstract: In the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, Harvard received numerous gifts of land and property from benevolent individuals as well as from the General Court of Massachusetts and the proprietors of several settlements in western Massachusetts. The Records of land and property owned by Harvard University contain records related to the land and property owned and managed by Harvard between 1643 and 1835 and include legal documents, leases and memoranda, surveyors' plans and appraisals of many of the properties, correspondence, bills, and other materials. Although management of the land holdings was largely the responsibility of the College Treasurer, these records demonstrate that Harvard's President and other staff were also actively involved in land-related concerns.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition information
acqinfo.p: The documents in this collection are University records and were acquired in the course of University business. Four of the documents were donated to the archives by Charles Holt Taylor in 1924 and 1931; this provenance information is noted at the item level in the following folder list.

accessrestrict.head: Researcher Access
accessrestrict.p: The Records of land and property owned by Harvard University are open for research. Pending conservation, materials in boxes 10, 11, 12, and 13 are closed to research due to their fragile state. These records have been severely damaged by mold, and some are so severely damaged that their contents are largely illegible (including all records related to Shawshin Farm in Billerica, Massachusetts). The contents of other damaged records are more clear and are listed in this finding aid.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: These records were previously dispersed both physically and intellectually, and classified under numerous call numbers. Some of the records were glued into bound volumes and required removal and rehousing. All of the records were re-processed in 2010 and brought together as a single collection. Re-processing involved a collection survey, re-housing in appropriate archival folders, and the creation of this finding aid.
This finding aid was created by Laura Morris in August 2010.

Preservation and description of the Records of land and property owned by Harvard University was generously supported by the Arcadia Foundation as part of the project Harvard in the Seventeenth and Eighteenth Centuries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Records of land and property owned by Harvard University document the Harvard Corporation's management and oversight of the University's land and property holdings from the mid seventeenth century into the nineteenth century. These properties extended across New England, in what is now Connecticut, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, and Maine, and also included revenue generated from the lease of an estate in England. Records include correspondence; leases, bonds, deeds, wills, and other legal documents; surveyors' plans and assessments of various lands; bills; statements of account; and memoranda. The records provide insight into land settlement in colonial New England; the challenges of marking boundaries and establishing legal ownership of land; economic difficulties in the colonies; and the legal, interpersonal, and financial challenges of managing extensive property holdings. Many of the records were created by these Harvard Treasurers: Thomas Danforth, Thomas Brattle, John White, Edward Hutchinson, Thomas Hubbard, John Hancock, Ebenezer Storer, Jonathan Jackson, John Davis, Ebenezer Francis, and Thomas Wren Ward.

It should be noted that some documents whose dates are between January 1 and March 25 in the years prior to 1752 have been cited with the double date convention, e.g. February 27, 1658/9. This convention has been followed only when the document itself indicates the date in such a manner. This convention was used in England and the North American colonies between 1582 and 1752. The first date refers to the year according to the Julian calendar, which began on March 25, while the second refers to the year according to the Gregorian calendar, which began on January 1.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Harvard-owned land in Rowley, Massachusetts was a bequest from Ezekiel Rogers (1590-1661), an English minister largely responsible for the settlement and incorporation of the town of Rowley in 1639. Rogers had served as minister of the Church at Rowley in Yorkshire (England) for almost two decades, but he was suspended from his duties there in 1638 because of increasing disagreement with the Church of England over religious doctrine. Rogers decided to flee to New England and, convincing twenty-two families among his congregation to accompany him, set sail on board the ship John of London in 1638. Also on board was the first printing press to arrive in America with several fonts of type, brought by the Reverend Joseph Glover (who died on the journey) and the printer Stephen Daye, accompanied by his sons, Stephen, Jr. and Matthew. The vessel arrived in Salem in December of 1638, and Rogers and his followers likely spent that winter in Salem. By the spring of 1639, they had settled in the town they would name Rowley (after the English village they had left behind); the town was incorporated on September 4, 1639. Rogers served as pastor there until his death on January 23, 1661.

In his will, Rogers specified that "all [his] houses, barn, and orchard, and all [his] lands, pastures and commonages and meadows" (approximately 26 parcels of land, and 196 acres in total) should be given to the town and church of Rowley following his wife Mary's death, but with a requirement that would prove significant: the land would only belong to the town and church on the condition that neither of the two teaching elders' positions should remain vacant for longer than four years. Rogers specified that, should those posts remain vacant for more than four years, all the lands he had bequeathed should "be [instead given] to the use of Harvard College, at Cambridge, in New England." He also gave Harvard "all [his] Latin books [...] and some English books." By 1700, the church had allowed the elders' positions to remain vacant for too long, and the land was reverted to Harvard. Various legal investigations and agreements ensued, including a 1704 decision to lease the land, and a 1734 decision to sell the land off in lots. The College began to sell their portion of Rogers' property in 1735, and many Rowley inhabitants - including Nathaniel Bradstreet, Thomas Lambert, and Daniel Hale - were among the purchasers. By 1764 all of the land in Rowley belonging to Harvard had been sold.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to the land and property in Rowley bequeathed to Harvard by Ezekiel Rogers, including documents created in the course of several legal disputes over ownership of the land and/or the right to access it. Many of the documents are manuscript copies of excerpts from the Rowley town records and appear to have been assembled for Harvard President Benjamin Wadsworth around 1736, as he was determining the best course of action in regards to the lands (presumably whether to continue leasing them, or to sell them). This series contains extracts of the wills of Thomas Barker, Joseph Jewett, Ezekiel Rogers, and Mary Rogers; legal agreements related to the division of the so-called "warehouse pasture"; a plan of the Rowley lands; leases (from the period that Harvard rented out the property); records of legal disputes over land ownership; committee reports; a surveyor's report; and depositions about trespassers, in addition to other documents.

II. Pequot land, 1652-1674

physdesc.extent: .07 cubic feet (7 folders)

scopecontent.p: The records in this series are related to land which formerly belonged to the Pequot tribe of Native Americans (located in what is now Connecticut and Rhode Island) which was granted to Harvard College by the General Court in the 1650s. A first tract of land, allocated on October 19, 1652, comprised 200 acres and a second, allocated on May 18, 1653, comprised 800 acres. These two grants were rendered null by a third allocation, made on May 19, 1658, which comprised “2,100 acres in Pequot Country.” Thomas Danforth, the Harvard Treasurer who was apparently responsible for negotiating these grants of land, was also awarded 300 acres of Pequot lands for his efforts.

This series contains manuscript copies of court decisions related to the land grants, including records related to disputes over whether or not the land in question was in the Massachusetts Bay Colony or the Connecticut Colony, and which colony had the right to allocate the land. Also included is a copy of the General Court's allocation of Pequot land to George Dennison and a copy of the court's decision to fine two men for trespassing on the College's Pequot lands. These records do not reveal the ultimate disposition of the Pequot lands belonging to Harvard, although Josiah Quincy wrote in The History of Harvard University that "the College obtained nothing by this gift."

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: In 1660, a highly successful Boston merchant named Henry Webb bequeathed to Harvard College a dwelling house and land in Boston, then rented at £13 per year, as well as a legacy of £50, the income and interest "to be improved either for the maintenance of some poor scholar, or otherwise for the best good of the College." The house and land extended from Cornhill, now part of Washington Street, to Devonshire Street, and the property was among the most profitable of the College real estate holdings because of its central location. For many years, beginning in 1831, the estate was rented to the publishers Little, Brown Co.

scopecontent.p: This series contains documents related to the Webb Estate, which comprised land, a dwelling house, and spaces for commercial business in Boston. Included are a manuscript copy of Henry Webb's will; leases of the estate, or portions of it, to many individuals; correspondence about the property; memoranda of agreement; documents related to difficulties in procuring rent from tenants; bills and receipts for maintenance work on buildings; and lists of tenants and their rents. Records related to the estate's commercial tenants provide information about small businesses operating in the early nineteenth century in Boston.

IV. Pennoyer Estate, 1670-1829

physdesc.extent: .26 cubic feet (30 legal folders and 2 oversize folders)

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: In his May 1670 will, British merchant William Pennoyer bequeathed £34 per annum from the rent of a 92-acre farm in Norfolk, England to Harvard College, so that "two Fellows and two Scholars [would] forever be educated and brought up in the College called Cambridge in New England, of which I desire one of them so often as occasion shall present, may be of the line of posterity of the said Robert Penoyr, if they be capable of it; and the other of the Colony of Nox, or of late called New Haven colony, if conveniently may be." Although the rental income would fluctuate from year to year and it was not always possible to find descendants of Pennoyer or scholars from New Haven to fund, Pennoyer's bequest provided scholarships for numerous Harvard students for over two centuries. By 1740, the original trustees of Pennoyer's estate had died, and from that year until the farm was sold in 1903 the Governors of Christ's Hospital in England found tenants for the farm, collected rent, and managed the property. A Harvard liaison in England then submitted the appropriate revenues to Harvard. By the late nineteenth century the farm had become unprofitable, largely because of an agricultural depression, and in 1897 the Harvard Corporation decided to sell it. Following several years of administrative challenges, the farm was sold in April 1903 for $4,029.52, which was added to the Pennoyer fund still maintained by Harvard.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to Pennoyer's bequest to Harvard and includes an extract from his will; legal documents concerning the distribution of his estate; and decades of correspondence with the individuals who took responsibility for transferring the estate rents from the trustees at the Governors of Christ's Hospital to Harvard College. These individuals included Henry Newman, Joseph Mico, Thomas Gibson, and Thomas Gibson, Jr., and their correspondence with the Harvard College Treasurer often includes statements of account and descriptions of purchases made on behalf of the College. Several letters refer to purchases of "philosophical apparatus" (scientific equipment) and books in London, which were then shipped to Massachusetts.

VI. Ward's Island (Bumpkin Island), 1680-1821

physdesc.extent: .20 cubic feet (23 legal folders and 3 oversize folders)

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Ward's Island, more commonly known as Bumpkin Island, is located in the Hingham Bay area of Boston Harbor. The island is approximately 62 acres in size, with half of the land considered "upland" and the other half "intertidal." It was once used by Native Americans, and after it was bequeathed to Harvard College by Samuel Ward in 1680 it was leased to tenant farmers. In the early nineteenth century, it was host to a fish-drying operation, and in the early twentieth century it housed a fish smelting operation. In 1900, Boston philanthropist Albert Burrage leased the island from Harvard and constructed a hospital for children with physical disabilities; the hospital burned in 1945. During the second world war Burrage also allowed the United States Navy to use the island as a training station. It was purchased by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in the 1980s and is now part of the Boston Harbor Islands National Recreation Area.

scopecontent.p: Samuel Ward, a resident of Charlestown, Massachusetts, bequeathed the island to Harvard College in 1680. He had either purchased it from the town of Weymouth or been granted it by the British Crown (sources differ), and he gave it to Harvard with the intention of providing a source of income from tenant farmers that would benefit Harvard students. Ward's will reads as follows: "I give the island living betwixt Hingham Hull called Bumpkin Island unto the Colledge and my mind that it be called by the name of Ward's Island." He made this gift "for the easement of the charges of the dyet of the students that are in Commons." This series contains Ward's deed of gift for the island and an extract from his will; leases of the island to tenants including Isaac Lobdell, Joseph Lobdell, Cromwell Lobdell, Solomon Lovell, Benjamin Lincoln, Martin Lincoln, Abner Lincoln, Daniel Spear, Josiah Adams, Josiah Davis(?), and Elijah Spear; and correspondence related to the property and its management.

did.unittitle: VII. Maine / "Eastern lands," 1690-1835

physdesc.extent: 1.62 cubic feet (2.5 document boxes and 23 oversize folders)

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: William and Mary's colonial charter of 1691 not only established Massachusetts as a province rather than a colony but also expanded Massachusetts' territory to encompass what was then known as the Province of Maine. As a result, between 1691 and the establishment of Maine's statehood in 1820, the expansive lands of Maine belonged to Massachusetts. Although frequently interrupted by war and unrest, the Maine lands (often referred to as "Eastern lands") slowly began to be settled in the early eighteenth century. In the years following the American Revolution, settlement in Maine increased as leaders of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts realized the potential economic boon of selling off parcels of land in Maine to generate revenue and help pay off war debt.

In 1783, the Commonwealth owned 17 million acres of Maine land. Numerous sales committees were formed in the following decades, and as early as 1786 approximately 100,000 acres of Maine land had been sold, primarily in small parcels of 150 acres and 500 acres. In order to increase sales, a land lottery was established, allowing interested buyers to purchase tickets which guaranteed a parcel of land, though its quality and location were left to chance. The lottery drawing, held in 1787, was less successful than had been hoped, though. Sales of Maine land continued into the nineteenth century, with agents specializing in the task and an increased focus on the persecution of squatters and timber thieves.

Squatters were the problem which most plagued those responsible for the Maine lands. Given the distance from Massachusetts, it was a great challenge to monitor the illegal settlement of the lots, and on many occasions squatters not only built homes and barns on the lands, but also removed timber and sold it, greatly reducing the land's value. The prevention of timber theft was increasingly a concern from the 1790s onward.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to Maine lands belonging to Harvard; it is divided into twelve subseries, according to geographic location or subject matter. One subseries contains records related to a land lottery held in 1787; another contains correspondence with Massachusetts senator and Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Maine, Prentiss Mellen, who served as a land agent in Maine for Harvard from 1808 to 1827; and another contains records of an auction held on August 5, 1835 to sell Harvard's remaining property in Maine. Correspondence in these records is often about boundary surveys; the sale of the lots; the value of the land per acre; trespassers and disputes regarding ownership; and the quality of the soil, timber, and stones on the lots.

did.unittitle: A. Merriconeag Neck, 1690-1729

scopecontent.p: Samuel Sewall and his wife, Hannah Hull Sewall, attempted to give a 1,000 acre tract of land in Maine called Merriconeag Neck to Harvard in the 1690s; their intented gift proved unsuccessful, though, and the land never came into Harvard's possession. This land was initially granted to John and Elizabeth Endicott on May 6, 1657. At that time, the Massachusetts General Court granted the Endicotts 1,000 acres, in a location of their choosing (which they did not specify). In 1658, John Hull - Hannah Hull Sewall’s father - purchased the grant of land from the Endicotts and requested that it be laid out at Merriconeag Neck, Maine. The Court agreed to this, and the land was later inherited by Hannah who, along with her husband, gave the land to Harvard.

Merriconeag Neck had gone unsurveyed for many years, though, because of the upheaval in Maine caused by the French and Indian Wars. Since it had not been surveyed, the land was not considered to be legally in the possession of the Sewalls, or later of Harvard. In November 1731, the Harvard College Overseers recommended taking legal action to secure the lands, and the Corporation initiated a lawsuit that would extend into 1733, when the Court decided against the College. Harvard not only lost the Merriconeag Neck lands, but also faced significant legal expenses as a result.

It should be noted that most of the records related to Merriconeag Neck are severely mold-damaged and in need of conservation. Their contents have not yet been determined and they are not listed in this finding aid. The records listed here consist of deed of sale for additional land to Samuel Sewall (presumably also part of the later Sewall gift, though this is currently not certain), a General Court grant, a map, and a surveyor's plot of the land.

scopecontent.p: In an effort to benefit financially from Massachusetts' land holdings in Maine, the General Court established a land lottery in 1786. Although 2,720 tickets were printed, only several hundred sold; Harvard was among the purchasers. Records in this subseries pertain to Harvard's purchases through the land lottery, held in the fall of 1787, and include lists of the lands drawn, lottery tickets, a chart, correspondence, and a memorandum.

scopecontent.p: Thomas Danforth (1623-1699), who served as Treasurer of Harvard College from 1650 to 1658 and as Steward from 1668 to 1682, had very sizable land holdings in Framingham, Massachusetts (formerly referred to as "Danforth's Farm.") He bequeathed multiple lots there to Harvard, stipulating that rental income from the tenants to whom he had awarded very long leases (999 years) should be paid to the College after his death. By providing such long leases at a low cost, Danforth encouraged settlement in Framingham. Although he died in 1699, it appears to have taken some time for Harvard to have received any financial benefit from his bequest. Tenants John Whitney and Moses Haven were informed by 1726 that they should thenceforward pay their rents to the Harvard Treasurer. Later tenants included Isaac Bowin and Benjamin Whitney, who would eventually transfer their leases to Daniel Haven. Harvard eventually sold the lots, to Moses Haven and Daniel Haven in 1767, and to Nathaniel Biglow at an unknown date. This series includes leases and other records related to multiple lots.

did.unittitle: XII. Narragansett farm, 1696-1829

physdesc.extent: 1.12 cubic feet (2 document boxes and 6 oversize folders)

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: On June 24, 1696, Chief Justice of the Province of Massachusetts Bay Samuel Sewall (1652-1730) and his wife, Hannah Hull Sewall, donated a 500 acre farm “at Petaquomscot in Narragansett Country,” Rhode Island to Harvard, specifying that the income generated from tenant farmers be used for "the support and education at the College, of youths, whose parents may not be of sufficient ability to maintain them there, especially such as should be sent from Petaquamscot, English or Indians." This farm constituted a portion of a larger tract of land in Narragansett country purchased by John Hull (Hannah's father) and others in 1657, in what was called the Petaquamscot purchase. Harvard leased the Narragansett farm to a series of tenant farmers, including Stephen Gardner, Paske Austin, Peter Reynolds, Peter Reynolds, Jr., Palmer Cleaveland, Nicholas Gardner, and Huling Gardiner. On January 4, 1809, an auction was held in which rights to remove the timber from individual portions of the farm were sold. On June 23, 1827, another auction was held, and the lots themselves were sold, ending Harvard's involvement with the land.

list.item: Quincy, Josiah. The History of Harvard University. Cambridge, Mass.: John Owen, 1840.
Bicknell, Thomas Williams. The History of the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations. New York: The American Historical Society, 1920.

scopecontent.p: This series contains records related to the Narragansett farm owned by Harvard. It includes the original deed of gift for the farm, as well as abundant correspondence with and about the farm's tenants, Stephen Gardner, Paske Austin, Peter Reynolds, Peter Reynolds, Jr., Palmer Cleaveland, Nicholas Gardner, and Huling Gardiner. It should be noted that there are variations in the spelling of several of these men's names, including Reynolds/Raynolds and Gardner/Gardiner. The farm was divided into smaller tracts of land, and thus often occupied by several tenants at once. This series also includes correspondence with local agents (most often lawyers) whom Harvard hired to manage the farm's affairs. These agents were Francis Willett, Joseph Denison, Rouse J. Helm, David Leonard Barnes, and Thomas Burgess, and their correspondence with the College Treasurer often provides valuable information about the tenants, their use of the land, and financial matters.

According to the tenants' leases, they were required to do the following: to plant apple orchards on the farm (with trees paid for by Harvard) and to prevent horned cattle from damaging the orchards; to clear a given number of acres each year, with the sometime assistance of goats supplied by the College; to pay taxes on the land; to keep the dwelling houses in good repair; to build fences, specifically "good four rail or Virginia fence," and - of course - to pay their rent. The tenants often failed to meet these requirements, though, and many of the records in this series concern those failures. One tenant, Peter Reynolds, was particularly lax in paying his rent, and in 1755 the College had him sent to jail as a consequence. There were also difficulties in receiving a particular rent payment, made in 1780 in the form of "a thousand weight of cheese," because of an embargo against its leaving Rhode Island. Nicholas Gardner, the tenant trying to transport this cheese to Cambridge, explained that "the state [of Rhode Island] hath an Imbargo on the same that it canot be carried out of the State as you will be informed by a coppy of the act of a sembly published in Newspaper which I send you."

The records in this series also contain information about the depreciation of paper currency, and the challenges of receiving payments in various currencies ("Spanish Mexico milled dollars," Sterling, "lawfull money," Continental dollars, etc.) whose stability fluctuated. There also appears to have been concern about counterfeit money. In addition, there are numerous reports on the condition of the farm which include information about the crops being grown, including Indian corn, rye, oats, tobacco, peaches, and apples, and the livestock being raised, which included horned cattle, horses, goats, and sheep. In addition, there are extensive records related to the January 4, 1809 auction of rights to the farm's timber and the June 23, 1827 auction of the land itself.

XIII. Townsend, 1733-1802

physdesc.extent: .16 cubic feet (14 legal folders and 1 oversize folder)

scopecontent.p: Records in this series pertain to a 250 acre lot in Townsend, Massachusetts granted to Harvard College by the General Court in 1719, at the same time another lot of the same size in neighboring Lunenburg was also granted to the College (See Series XI). Although Townsend was within the borders of Massachusetts at the time of the grant, it was determined to be part of New Hampshire when the province line between Massachusetts and New Hampshire was established in 1741, and thus no longer College property. As an indemnity, the General Court granted another tract of land in Massachusetts to Harvard in 1765, but that land was re-granted to another party at a later date, overriding the College's rights to it. This series contains correspondence about the land, several plots drawn by surveyors, bills for survey work, memoranda, and a letter explaining the claim that the land lay in New Hampshire.

XIV. Waltham farm (Rogers Farm), 1737-1826

physdesc.extent: .55 cubic feet (1 document box and 5 oversize folders)

scopecontent.p: In 1738, Harvard purchased a farm of approximately 160 acres in Waltham, Massachusetts from Anthony Caverly with proceeds from the sale of the Rowley lands bequeathed to the College by Ezekiel Rogers (See Series I). The farm was often referred to as Rogers Farm, in honor of the source of the purchasing funds, and it was leased to generate income. Although some tenants paid their rent in "lawful silver money," others paid with beef, pork, Indian corn, cider, butter, cheese, potatoes, rye, oats, barley, melons, squashes, flax, and hay. Several Harvard employees were among the tenants, including Hollis Professor of Mathematics and Natural Philosophy Samuel Williams and College Steward Caleb Gannett. The other tenants documented in these records were William Hagar, Thomas Dean, Ephraim Pierce (sometimes spelled "Peirce"), Jonathan Sanderson, and Nahum Hardy. The farm was sold in 1835 for $5,000, which became the Ezekiel Rogers Fund.

This series contains records related to the rental of the farm, as well as several plans of the land and buildings drawn by surveyors. Included are the 1738 deed of sale from Caverly to Harvard, memoranda about labor performed on the farm by tenants (which was taken into account when determining the rent they owed), leases and minutes for leases, statements of account with tenants and with individuals who made repairs on the property; bonds; memoranda; a certification of taxes made by the Waltham assessors; reports on the farm's production; and accounts of timber from the farm either sold or brought to the Harvard wood-yard.
Of note in this series are two documents created by John Hancock during his tenure as Treasurer of Harvard College.

XV. Coggan's Marsh and Stoughton's Marsh, 1654/5-1823

physdesc.extent: .32 cubic feet (26 legal folders and 3 oversize folders)

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: In 1652, Boston merchant John Coggan donated a tract of between 50 and 70 acres of salt marsh in Chelsea, Massachusetts, to Harvard College, "for the use of the President and Fellows of the said College, so long as they and their successors profess and teach the good knowledge of God's Holy Word and works." The tract, which was thereafter called Coggan's Marsh, was located within the larger Rumney Marsh, and the College leased it to generate income. Harvard is believed to have sold the land in 1831, to a Dr. Edward H. Robbins.

Former Massachusetts Governor William Stoughton (1631-1701) also gave a parcel of marsh to the College; this bequest of approximately 5 acres of marsh land in Dorchester was finalized in 1702, the year after his death, and was thenceforward called Stoughton's Marsh. Stoughton specified that income from the marsh, along with income from Stoughton's Pasture (See Series XVIII) should be used to finance scholarships "in the first place, to a scholar of the town of Dorchester, and if there be none such, to one of the town of Milton, and if in want of such, then to any other well deserving, that shall be most needy."

XVI. Gridley Estate, 1761-1792

physdesc.extent: .09 cubic feet (9 legal folders)

scopecontent.p: The records in this series pertain to property in Boston, near Fort Hill, which formerly belonged to a man named Isaac Gridley. The property consisted of a brick dwelling house, another dwelling house, several parcels of land, warehouses, and a ropewalk. The circumstances surrounding Harvard College's possession of the Gridley estate are not entirely clear. The College was granted the estate in a 1770 court decision (College Treasurer Thomas Hubbard was formally awarded the property via a writ of habere facias possessionem in 1771; he had sued for ejectment), but the particulars of the case are not yet understood.

The records in this series primarily consist of copies of legal decisions related to the Gridley estate and records pertaining to Harvard's sale of the property in 1792. Of note is a petition and memorial from Jeffrey Richardson, a rope maker and tenant on the property for 15 years who was interested in purchasing the estate and claimed he was treated unfairly by Harvard Treasurer Ebenezer Storer. Although Richardson pleaded for what he believed was his right to purchase the estate, it was ultimately sold to Thomas Davis instead.

XVII. Winchendon, 1784-1808

physdesc.extent: .26 cubic feet (26 legal folders)

scopecontent.p: Isaac Royall, Jr. (1719–1781), a prominent colonist whose family wealth was generated through the slave trade, moved from Antigua to Medford, Massachusetts in the early eighteenth century. On Dec. 28, 1752, Royall purchased - along with James Otis, John Chandler, and Caleb Dana - a tract of land consisting of 928 acres from the Province of Massachusetts Bay. The land was located in what came to be known as Royalston. (N.B. Although many of the records in this series refer to the land in question as being in the town of Winchendon, it is believed that the property was technically located in Royalston, just west of Winchendon.) Royall bequeathed his share of this land, approximated at 200 acres, to Harvard College, for the creation of a Royall Professorship of Law. When he died of smallpox in 1781, the land became the possession of the College.

Records in this series pertain to the Winchendon land and include correspondence, memoranda, a quitclaim deed, statements of account, a surveyor's plan of the land, an appraisal of its value, and many offers to purchase the land. Of note is information pertaining to William Robbins' claim to 93 acres of the land, which was considered partially valid, reducing Harvard's portion of the property to 133 acres. This was sold on March 1, 1808 to Benjamin May, Eliot Payson, and David Beaman.

Although numerous Harvard publications cite Royall's land donations as constituting 2,100+ acres, the records related to Winchendon and Granby lands in this collection suggest that the bequest was perhaps smaller in size.

scopecontent.p: In addition to the Winchendon lands (See Series XVII), prominent colonist Isaac Royall also bequeathed land located in Granby, Massachusetts to Harvard, for the creation of a Royall Professorship of Law. This land, estimated at between 800 and 900 acres in size, came into Harvard's possession after Royall died of smallpox in 1781. Records in this series include offers from various individuals to purchase the land, correspondence about its value and about trespassers, a surveyor's plan and description of the land, and minutes for the conveyance of the land to Joseph Eastman, who purchased it in 1796. The records also include Eastman's bond to the President and Fellows of Harvard College.

Although numerous Harvard publications cite Royall's land donations as constituting 2,100+ acres, the records in this collection related to Winchendon and Granby lands suggest that the bequest was perhaps smaller in size.

scopecontent.p: The records in this series pertain to a variety of properties belonging to the College. In many instances, the circumstances surrounding the lands' becoming College property are not known, and the records appear to be incomplete. Some documents in this series were apparently compiled as summaries of dealings at numerous properties and thus refer to lands represented in other series of this collection; they are placed in this series because they pertain to multiple properties and were not records compiled in the course of managing those individual properties. This series consists of deeds, committee appointments, reports, memoranda, a writ of execution, a letter of attorney, a lease, and property valuations. These records pertain to lands in Andover, "Pequot country," Boston, Cambridge, Charlestown, Concord, Lincoln, Bedford, Lancaster, Newburyport, Menotomy, Woburn, Boxborough, Rumney Marsh, and a property called "the Gore" in western Massachusetts.

did.unittitle: Manuscript copy of “Mr. Ward’s” conveyance of 600 acres of land “near Andover by Merrimake” to Harvard College on Dec. 10, 1646, copied in 1647

scopecontent.p: Mr. Ward was the Reverend Nathaniel Ward.

did.unittitle: Deed of gift from John Newgate to Harvard College of £5 annually “for ever” from revenues of his Rumney Marsh farm, June 11, 1650

scopecontent.p: Annotation on verso indicates that gift was entered into Suffolk County records of deeds, March 15, 1702.

did.unittitle: General Court’s appointment of committee to consider Harvard’s land concerns, Oct. 20, 1663, and Court’s initial response to the committee’s findings, May 18, 1664

scopecontent.p: The committee consisted of Francis Willoughby, Daniel Gookin, Richard Russell, Thomas Danforth, Zachariah Syms, and Jonathan Mitchell. The Court response refers to the 600 acres from Mr. Ward.

did.unittitle: Deed of gift from Theodore Atkinson to the President and Fellows of Harvard College for land near Boston, Oct. 13, 1671

scopecontent.p: According to Josiah Quincy's The History of Harvard University, Harvard ultimately “obtained nothing” from this gift.

did.unittitle: Deed of mortgage for land near the Mill Bridge in Boston, from William Smith and Martha Smith to John Richards, (unknown month) 19, 1686/7

scopecontent.p: Richards was Harvard's Treasurer, and he bequeathed this mortgage and another one to Harvard. They became the possessions of the College when Richards died in 1694. Notes on verso from 1687, 1694, 1708, 1714/15, and 1716, including one from Harvard Treasurer John White. Deed explains that the land in question was occupied by tenant Henry Godfrey and bounded on the SE by a highway leading from Mill Bridge “towards the second meeting house”; that William Smith was a cordwainer; and that Richards gave the Smiths £58 in exchange for the deed of mortgage.

did.unittitle: Deed of mortgage for land near Roxbury Gate in Boston, from Seth Perry and Dorothy Perry to John Richards, June 28, 1693

scopecontent.p: Recto signed by Seth Perry, Dorothy Perry, Jeremiah Dummer, Benjamin Eliott, Eliezer Moody, and Joseph Webb. Verso is annotated by the executors of the estate of Harvard Treasurer John Richards (Anne Richards, John Foster, Josiah Eldridge, and William Gill). This mortgage, and the repayments of Richards’ initial loan to the Perrys, was bequeathed to Harvard and came into the College's possession when Richards died in 1694.

did.unittitle: Memorandum about various tracts of land and property belonging to Harvard College, 1646-1696

scopecontent.p: Includes information about Nathaniel Ward’s gift of 600 acres, the Pequot lands, a gift from a Mr. Dodridge, and a gift from Major R. Sedgwick of “two small shops in Boston,” which was somehow transformed into a ship tavern owned by William Phillips, who in turn paid £20 per year in “rent.”

did.unittitle: Manuscript extracts of deeds and other records regarding gifts of land to Harvard College, 1650-1719

scopecontent.p: Includes extracts from wills of Samuel Sewall (Merriconeag Neck and Narragansett farm), John Newgate (Rumney Marsh), John Coggan (Coggan’s Marsh), Samuel Ward (Ward’s Island), and Theodore Atkinson (land near Boston), as well as donations made by the Proprietors of Rutland and the General Court.

did.unittitle: Manuscript copy of grants of Cambridge land, given by the Proprietors of Common Lands in Cambridge to Harvard College, 1662-1724

scopecontent.p: Note on verso: “Records of some of the College Lands in Cambridge Recd from Mr. Andrew Bordman Town Clerk of Cambridge. July 25, 1727.”

did.unittitle: Nicholas Sever and Edward Wigglesworth’s report on College lands at Menotomy, March 20, 1726/7

scopecontent.p: The tenants at Menotomy were Mr. Hill and Mr. Swan.

did.unittitle: Writ of execution against property of Jonathan Procter and James Procter, on behalf of Thomas Hubbard, Jan. 27, 1753

scopecontent.p: Notes on verso indicate that Woburn land belonging to the Procters (9 acres) was appraised and seized on Feb. 7, 1753. The appraisers were Benjamin Johnson, James Fowle, and John Turner. Middlesex County Sheriff Richard Foster notes that he was unable to locate any additional property belonging to the Procters. Other notes on the verso indicate that the lot was sold to John Caldwell.

did.unittitle: Letter of attorney from the President and Fellows of Harvard College to Theophilus Parsons, April 7, 1800

scopecontent.p: Signed by Joseph Willard.

did.unittitle: Memorandum regarding Elijah Rice’s offer to purchase College lot between Westminster and Fitchburg (Massachusetts) called the Gore, Aug. 25, 1809

scopecontent.p: This lot of land (250 acres) is possibly the one granted to the College after it was acknowledged that their lot in Townsend was actually in New Hampshire.

did.unittitle: Lease of “house and lot in Cambridge called No. 5” to William Brown, March 31, 1812

scopecontent.p: The house and lot rented to Brown are described as being “opposite the [Harvard] President’s house” and formerly occupied by Levi Hedge. Annotations indicate receipt of rent payments from 1812-1816. Signed by John Davis and William Brown.

did.unittitle: Valuation of Oliver Wood and Alden Wood’s Boxborough farm by the town assessors, Aug. 24, 1821, and receipts and notes related to mortgage of the property, 1821-1827

scopecontent.p: The assessors were Joseph Stone, Ephraim Robins, and Samuel Hayward.

did.unittitle: Memorandum from register of probate concerning Concord real estate of the late John Meriam, April 16, 1822
Samuel Hoar’s certification about sale and ownership of the late John Meriam’s farm in Concord, April 14, 1823 and related document, undated

scopecontent.p: It appears that Meriam’s widow sold the farm to Ebenezer Englesby, but that Samuel Hoar, superintendent of the farm, also benefited financially.

did.unittitle: Manuscript excerpts from Worcester registry of deeds related to Horatio Carter and George Carter’s land titles in Lancaster, June 7, 1823

scopecontent.p: Artemas Ward (1776-1850) was Registrar of Deeds and created this document.

did.unittitle: Vote of Harvard Corporation to permit street construction on College land in Boston, March 7, 1825, and blank quit claim deed for this purpose

scopecontent.p: The agreement was that the College would grant the City of Boston ownership of the part of the land on which the road was to be built.

did.unittitle: Samuel Hoar’s receipt to Ebenezer Francis for John Meriam’s note and mortgage deed for Concord farm, March 23, 1827
Manuscript copy of deed of sale for marsh land in Cambridge to Edmund Monroe, Jan. 8, 1829

scopecontent.p: Munroe paid $700 for the land, which was given to Harvard by Royal Makepeace on April 24, 1824.

did.unittitle: Manuscript copy of deed of sale for a “moiety or half part” of land in Charlestown to Edward Hearsey, March 31, 1829

scopecontent.p: Hearsey purchased the land for $315; it had been a gift to Harvard from Thomas Cary and had previously been owned by Samuel Cary.

did.unittitle: Manuscript copy of deed of sale for land on Greenleaf’s wharf in Newburyport to Seth Sweetser, Dec. 29, 1829

scopecontent.p: The property was part of the Cary Estate. Sweetser paid $550 for it.

did.unittitle: Manuscript copy of Thomas H. Darling’s deed for land in Concord, Lincoln, and Bedford, May 4, 1830

scopecontent.p: The land in Concord included John Meriam’s farm; this deed is for eight parcels of land.
